Posts.Content: Time will help, as each week/month went by I got more accepting. I did choose to dive in and learn all I could about the disease and treatment options which helped, as I wasn't just waiting. Stay busy! Denis
Posts.Signature: 65 YO healthy man PSA had been 4.1/2 for a couple of years, PSA 5/1/17 4.6, Multiparametric MRI, 5/15/17 showed lesion 13 core needle biopsy 3 cores positive 3+3 and one positive in the lesion, may be overlap All cores less than 30% 8/22/17 - second opinion pathology shows a small amount of (3+4) in one core, < 5%, ordered decipher to inform next steps 9/27/17 -Decipher test shows intermediate risk so now exploring treatment options. 2/6/18 - completed HDR BT 5/3/18 Post HDR BT PSA 1.3 9/18/18 PSA 1.2 4/1/19 PSA 1.0 Testosterone 475 Thanks, Denis "One day at a time"

Posts.Content: Sounds like you have good resources available. While I did not do surgery the same question applies to choosing an RO. For me, it was a combination of competence and communication skills. I was fortunate to have a great uro at Yale, who was the best communicator. When I then decided on HDR BT, I was again blessed with a guy who I felt I could talk to easily and he also is an experienced expert in HDR-BT. So I would say trust your gut! Denis

Posts.Title: tough week but good outcomes.

Posts.Content: Okay, post HDR BT about a week and everything is normal. No soreness, no urination issue, actually no SEs. unfortunately, we had a family tragedy, as my first wife passed away suddenly. My wife and I went to NC to support my two daughters. They asked me to do the eulogy, which I did and it was an amazing service for our family. My daughters struggled with all of this, especially having to make the decision to discontinue life support. In parallel to all of this my GI doc told me there were two polyps from my last colonoscopy. I am on the annual plan due to family history. Well, I couldn't get the doc to tell me the path report and with all the emotions I was convinced it was bad news. Fortunately, I was wrong, benign. Emotions and cancer don't go well together. As to my PC, I now wait three months for the PSA. Feeling relieved and grateful. Denis

Posts.Title: Encouraging Radiation Study

Posts.Content: "76.3% of the RP patients had Gleason score 7 vs 72.8% for EBRT vs 57.3% for BT, p = 0.0001. Median initial PSA was 7.4 for RP, 9.4 for EBRT, and 8.3 for BT, p < 0.0001. Importantly, neoadjuvant androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) was given to 58.9% of EBRT patients vs 12.7% of BT vs. only 0.6% for RP, p < 0.0001. An additional 14% of BT received supplemental external radiation." Sure there are differences in the populations. The real key is this was not a pure study of monotherapies and I still find the results encouraging. Denis

Posts.Title: Ten Year Treatment Outcomes of RP vs. EBRT vs. BT

Posts.Content: Am I living or dying? Cancer throws a wrench into that question. My experience for this last year or so has been one of many thoughts, feelings, and questions. The vivid memory of that Urologist telling me you have prostate cancer is as if it happened yesterday. Shock, fear, and loneliness surrounded me that day. My wife was away in Hawaii visiting her daughter and we expected the doctor visit to be like the last and a message you have nothing to worry about. So, the shock was exponential based on my expectations. The doctor babble about surgery and even suggested we could get it scheduled in the next number of weeks, even though I was a Gleason 6, 4 cores and none above 30%. I happened to have taken my motorcycle to the appointment, so when I left I rode by the ocean to try to process what had happened. It was a long night and many long nights the next 6 months as my wife and I tried to figure out what to do. I am a thinker, researcher, reader so I dove into the literature, attended PCRI conference and attended a weekend with other PC folks. I changed Uros and went to Yale and loved my doc there. They did a second opinion on my biopsy samples and upgraded one core to G7 (3+4) <5%. We did a genomic test that came back less than favorable and decided to treat. My great doc at Yale was newer in the profession and had done 200 robotic prostatectomies. So, we decided to move our treatment to Florida and had an appointment with Dr. Patel who has done more than 13,000. In the meantime we met with an RO and once informed about other choices, we choose HDR BT. The treatment and recovery were easy and now I am in the wait and watch what happens to my PSA. At its height it was 5.7, 3 months post op it was 1.3. I have my next blood draw in a couple of weeks. Living or dying? I am active on a couple of forums and of late it seems like there is a rash of reoccurrences and guys are dealing with more advanced treatments. A week or so ago I got a little down about this fact and started worrying about my case. I am blessed with another malady that focuses on living one day at a time and I have been practicing that for more than 40 years. It became clear to me that when I am worried, stressed, upset, etc. I am more dying than living. I have had sleepless nights, high anxiety and other negative feelings this last year but as time passes I seem to have them much less. As a matter of fact, the only time I think about PC is when I log onto a forum and interact with fellow PC brothers. As to my next PSA test I have no real feelings about it right now. I am in a place of acceptance and know there is nothing I can do to change the state of my PC today. One tool I use often is to make a gratitude list, for which I have many, many things and people to be grateful for! So, I choose to live. Living for me includes showing up as a grateful and helpful person. I know that through helping others I get the focus off of self. As I was contemplating this writing I thought, I certainly am closer to the end of my life than the beginning of my life. I am 66 years old, but I am healthy, happy and have a lot to share and help others. To me, that is what living is about. Living is about giving! I see this every day on the forum as guys support each other and help new guys. We (in my opinion) have a responsibility to help others, particularly those who are just starting this journey. Cancer has enabled me to form new friendships and allowed me to recommit to living. Sure, there are dark times, but I have the choice right now to turn on the light, to choose to be alive, to reach out and help others. One interesting gift I have received is fitness. I have always been active and tried to take care of myself and this last six months I have double down on my fitness and feel more fit and alive than almost any time in my life. I write this on a plane heading to North and South Dakota with my wife for two weeks of exploration and focused couple time. What a gift. I have no idea what my future holds concerning my health and I committed to minimizing the time I fret about the future, as I find that to be in the dying mode not living. We have a choice to show up right now alive or dying, let's choose living!

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: The most confusing part of having PC for me and what I hear others say is deciding what to do! The need to learn about the options, the side effects, and the relapse rates all figure into to it. Certainly, we need a good diagnosis and staging info to make this decision. Also, there is a risk part of the decision, the risk of not choosing the best, the risk of acting too soon, etc. The below link is a decision tree that I find useful. For me, the other critical factors trust in my Uro. My first Uro and I did not connect, within 15 minutes of telling me I had cancer he was talking about scheduling surgery and I was G6, four cores, all less than 33%. My current Uro is willing to sit and talk, discusses the research, and seems well balanced and truly caring! In the end, it is my wife's and my decision and hopefully, we have enough good research and trust to make the most informed decision possible when we make it. I also believe there will be a series of decisions along this journey. I do find forums like this most helpful in the decision process. Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: I am new at this PC adventure and in the early decision-making state. I read a great deal, am active on a few forums, have a great Doc and feel well informed. Yesterday on a forum a Gentleman shared his AS story and the shock of going from G6 to G9 in five years. A great discussion in the thread occurred. To say it set me on my heels is not an overstatement. I have been through the typical emotional wringer many of us go through in the early days of diagnosis. I had become comfortable with following AS at Yale. I meet with my Uro today, hopefully, to get Decipher results and create a short-term plan. And the post mentioned has me full of doubt. I also had this thought that my fear of intervention (which I believe will happen at some point) is really about the SEs of intervention. So, the bet I am making is it worth delaying SEs for some period and risking advanced disease and possibly metastasis? At the PCRI conference, I met a big group of men on AS who were very happy. A few who had interventions after AS for many years and were pleased with their decision. I believe there is great value in AS for many. Am I one of them is the key question? As I reflect on the many tough decisions I have made in my life, none seem as difficult as this one. The impreciseness of the tools we have, the complexity of this stupid little gland, and the bias we all have makes this a most difficult decision. What do I know? Well I know I have positive cores with second opinion grading. I dont know if there is a worst disease that the biopsy missed but probability wise there is a greater chance that I have worse than better cancer. More cases are upgraded than downgraded. I also know many guys who have had /are having a good run at AS and even those who intervened were able to keep the window of survivability open. I am getting clearer, for me, that AS is a good strategy that really is delayed intervention for many. In the recent Netherlands study, the following was found: https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...e-netherlands/ Here is what Verbeek et al. reported in London:  Of the 900 eligible patients, o 223 (24.8 percent) were initially placed on active surveillance. o 312 (34.7 percent) elected immediate radiation therapy. o 365 (40.6 percent) elected immediate radical prostatectomy.  The 15-year rates of metastasis-free survival were o 96.9 percent for the men initially placed on active surveillance. o 96.6 percent for the men treated with immediate radiation therapy. o 97.7 percent for the men treated with immediate radical prostatectomy.  The 15-year rates of prostate cancer-specific survival were o 97.2 percent for the men initially placed on active surveillance. o 97.5 percent for the men treated with immediate radiation therapy. o 98.5 percent for the men treated with immediate radical prostatectomy.  There were no statistically significant differences between the groups of patients with regard to either metastasis-free or prostate cancer-specific survival. Well, I am a bit lost as to my next steps. I do trust my doc and today will have a gut discussion. I am confident the path will be clearer later today and my wife and I can decide the best course for us. I am open to input for all. Well time to go for a run and let the spirits guide me! Be well all! Denis

Posts.Title: Which Treatment????

Posts.Content: Thanks All. it was a smooth day, all the professionals were attentive and caring. For prep, I had to do two enemas, and two showers with surgical soap. No eating from noon the day before and no drinking after midnight. I arrived at 6 am and was in prep room by 630. They did vitals and IV. The anesthesiologist came and talked about sedation. The first step in the procedure was to insert the catheters in the prostate, 15 of them. And a urinary catheter for the day. This was done under general anesthesia. I also had an MRI in this process but don't remember it. This was to ensure the caths were correctly placed. They used a rectal ultrasound to place the caths. I then woke up and brought to the radiation lab where they inserted tubes into catheters. The tubes were hooked up to a machine that delivered the radiation. This was done by physicists, they left the room. I was alone in the room for maybe a half hour while they did the treatments. They then brought me back to the recovery room and waited my turn to have the caths removed, this time under propofol. During the awake periods, I felt discomfort/pressure in my urinary and prostate area. Occasions jabs of discomfort. about every 5 minutes they were offering pain meds but I did not need any. After they removed the caths the go home test was to urinate. I waited about 15 minutes in recovery and then was able to pee. A tinge of blood in the urine. Went home, had a nice dinner. I have two minor issues. My perineum is sore, had to wear loose clothes last night, no tighty whitees And when I urinate there is a burning sensation at the tip of my penis. They gave me an OTC med for the burning. It turns your urine bright orange. There is one other issue and that is they put e back on Flomax, and it causes insomnia in me. Happened after biopsy and I had hoped it was anxiety. I am going to try taking it in the morning and see if that helps, if not find an alternative. I feel great this morning. I go back in two weeks for the second and final treatment. . Denis

Posts.Title: HDRBT begins today

Posts.Content: I am about a week into the time to treat decision phase (even that is unsure). I had 4 cores 3+3 and one was upgraded to 3+4, decipher test showed intermediate risk. My doc who I trust suggests it is time to treat. On these forums, I get many different opinions, which is why I am on them. I totally seek diversity of thought and experience to help sort out my next steps. This morning I read few RALP stories and the picture got grim. The key question and I am sure this has been asked many times, is How do you sort out the best treatment, not the best docs? For now, I am assuming treatment is the right answer. I do plan to visit with a Radiation Oncologist. Thanks in advance for your input. Denis

Posts.Title: I am so frustrated while trying to schedule first biopsy! (Long Rant!)

Posts.Content: Today I am at peace and grateful for the many gifts in my life. While I am not grateful to have cancer, I am very grateful for the people I have met, the wonderful medical professionals who go out of their way to help me. I am also extremely grateful I live in a country where quality medical care is available. During the last six months, I have experienced an array of emotions, unsureness, and loneliness that were not pleasant. However, I also met all of you, men and women at GFMPH and at the PCRI conference. I also have found many existing friends who have PC. The level of conversation is much different when you talk to another man with PC. I have so many gifts and those related to PC include the ability to learn, to trust, to be inquisitive and to be so thankful for those who help me on this journey. The ability to connect and share is such a gift. During this holiday season, I have been reflecting on the gifts related to my cancer and am very grateful. So, I wish you all peace and a wonderful holiday season. I also want to thank you all for being on these forums and other get-togethers where you have helped me come to grips with my disease and options. You are very special men and women! Peace, Denis

Posts.Title: Alfuzosin and PSA

Posts.Content: I looked at most recent publications on the NIH PubMed site and compiled these, all have good outcomes for HDR-BT. What seems odd to me, still, is why isn't this treatment more common? I get there are not as many docs who specialize in it, I get there is less money to be made, and I get there are fewer fellowships to get trained. But what I gather is it is least invasive, similar success to other treatments, easy post-op recovery, and minimal tempory side effects. 22 days from first treatment! HDR-BT Research 1. The evolution of brachytherapy for prostate cancer. June 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28664931 2. HDR brachytherapy of prostate cancer  two years experience in Greater Poland Cancer Centre Sept 2009 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5086480/ 3. Under-utilisation of high-dose-rate brachytherapy boost in men with intermediate-high risk prostate cancer treated with external beam radiotherapy. Dec 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29271056 4. Pattern of relapse and dose received by the recurrent intraprostatic nodule in low- to intermediate-risk prostate cancer treated with single fraction 19 Gy high dose-rate brachytherapy. Nov 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29137956 5. Impact of five-tiered Gleason grade groups on prognostic prediction in clinical stage T3 prostate cancer undergoing high-dose-rate brachytherapy. Nov 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28905446 6. Accuracy and variability of high-dose-rate prostate brachytherapy needle tip localization using live two-dimensional and sagittally reconstructed three-dimensional ultrasound. Sept 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28764882 7. High-dose-rate brachytherapy boost for prostate cancer: Comparison of three different fractionation schemes. Sept 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28754301 8. Long-term prognostic significance of rising PSA levels following radiotherapy for localized prostate cancer - focus on overall survival. June 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28615058 9. Nationwide, Multicenter, Retrospective Study on High-Dose-Rate Brachytherapy as Monotherapy for Prostate Cancer. Apr2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28333018 10. Dosimetric comparison between treatment plans of patients treated with low-dose-rate vs. -dose-rate interstitial prostate brachytherapy as monotherapy: Initial findings of a randomized clinical trial. May 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28325472 11. High-dose rate brachytherapy as monotherapy in prostate cancer: A systematic review of its safety and efficacy. May 2017 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27496770 12. Fractionated high-dose-rate brachytherapy as monotherapy in prostate cancer: Does implant displacement and its correction influence acute and late toxicity? Nov 2016 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27364871 13. Toxicity and quality of life after high-dose-rate brachytherapy as monotherapy for low- and intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Nov 2015 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26409832 14. High-Dose-Rate Brachytherapy as Monotherapy for Intermediate- and High-Risk Prostate Cancer: Clinical Results for a Median 8-Year Follow-Up. Mar 2016 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26238951 15. Is high dose rate brachytherapy reliable and effective treatment for prostate cancer patients? A review of the literature. June 2015 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25819287

Posts.Title: HDR BT literature search all positive

Posts.Content: I also was G6 for a couple of months until the second opinion and a bit <5% g7 3+4. I took the next 5 months to study all the options and get multiple doctors opinions before I choose treatment. All the main treatments have the same survival rate statistically. I would suggest you become expert t potential side effect and post-op recovery before making a choice. If you want to hear about HDR BT ( I finished the second treatment two weeks ago message me and I will gladly give you my number). I found great comfort in talking live with guys who went before me. Denis

Posts.Title: New Member, Wife

Posts.Content: Diesledog, our numbers are nearly identical. I find we are in a most precarious position. The new guidelines for PC put us in the intermediate risk favorable, see link below. The agreed to treatment options include AS with a caution of risk for metastasis. My Uro is suggesting AS and thinks I am a good candidate, still waiting for Decipher results to confirm. I am nervous and unsure ever other day. My internal debate is about the risk reward I am taking with either choice. One ray of hope is the possibility that the G7 was inaccurate and second opinion. SOme percentage of RPs get down graded. I am leaning into AS, at least for a year or until next biopsy, to inform decision. I find it to be a tough place to be on the edge of decision. Clearly, there is more risk for me to be on AS than those in the low or very low-risk category. I leave today for the PCRI conference and hope to get some clarity and new info. I wish you well. Denis http://www.auanet.org/guidelines/cli...uideline-2017)

Posts.Title: Disappointing 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: During my learning phase and decision making, I had considered RP and was doing kegels to strengthen sphincter. Well, now I am post HDR BT about two weeks and cannot stop my uring flow when standing. I can when seated. I am on Alfuzosin, because flowmax caused insomnia. I am running an experiment and have stopped taking alfuzosin to see if that is the issue. Anyone else experience this? Denis

Posts.Title: Choosing The Right Treatment - Hopkins

Posts.Content: Justin welcome and I get the indecision. I had been wrestling for months with what to do. For me, it is about really a slow and deep learning curve and deciding what is of most value. I had been heading the RP route and made a different decision and will start HDR BT is 10 days. I am not proposing that for you. Rather take time to really learn about all the treatment options, all the implications for each treatment, and the post-op for each treatment. I believe only with that info fully understood will you be able to have confidence in your decision. I wish you well. Denis

Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Bias will kill us! I know from personal experience that once I make a decision I start to ignore and rule out other important information that may not support my opinion. I was set on doing RP because of a ignorance about radiation. Fortunately, I met a doctor who explained it in a way that caused me to pause and motivated me to learn more about HDR-BT. My bias almost eliminated this option for me. Now I also know there was this internal pressure to make a decision and get treatment. The idea that there was CANCER in me was causing emotional decision making not factual decision making. There also may be some value one I am set on a treatment plan to focus on that, so the focused FB pages may serve a value. As you all know the decision on treatment is a very difficult for some of us. Having a forum like this one was a great tool in my decision making.

Posts.Title: Letter to the Editor: PCa Opinions are Becoming as Intense as Politics

Posts.Content: Based on numerous factors it is highly probable I will seek treatment for my PC in the spring of next year. Probably surgery but still need to do a lot of investigating and discussions with docs. Given that I will treat, what can I do to best prepare for it? I am healthy, at a healthy BMI, very active, don't smoke or drink, and I am a vegetarian. I am a runner, bike rider, and golfer. I get hours of exercise each day. I know that I want to strengthen urinary sphincter via kegel exercises. What else for those that have been through treatment? Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: Should I have another biopsy

Posts.Content: Thanks another I agree prob have an extra 10 pounds. My D has to be fine. I do plan adding strengh training. The timing issue is a question. Technically I am low risk category still. We are doing another MRI to see if there are any changes. Have a big trip to Hawaii to take care of grandkids in November and ski trip in March. Hoping to do those and use time to verify what to do. However, if PSA or other indicator say otherwise I will act. Thanks Denis
Posts.Title: Preparing for intervention

Posts.Content: MF thanks for sharing your journey. I agree and will heed advice. 3 months no golf!?!?!?
Posts.Title: Preparing for intervention

Posts.Content: I just got back from an awesome golf school in Arizona. It was called Vision54, which is about setting audacious goals, the score of 54 is birding every hole. One of the key components of the school is about being present and mindful when int he play box. They use think box, play box, and memory box as phases of the golf game. In the play box, we are more successful if we are committed and clear about our intentions. The PC journey is similar for me. Early on I spent way to much time in the think box and much of my thinking carried into today or the play box, contaminating it. Sure I needed to learn about PC, make decisions about treatment and even feel the fear of having PC. But today I can set that aside when I step into the play box or life. And I can create new memories of a life well lived. Being present is a gift to self. Denis

Posts.Title: golf school and PC

Posts.Content: I have some experience with research reports, both writing and reading. In this forum, we come across many and are trying to make sense of them. One of the best tips I ever got about research is the following 4 steps. 1. Practical problem (does X effect Y)? 2. Statistical problem (does a sample population have a relationship between X and Y)? 3. Statistical solution (what is the correlation between X and Y)? 4. Practical solution (eliminate X due to the relationship with Y). A couple of key thoughts on the generic research report. Most of the research that I have seen on PC is correlational research, which looks at is there a relationship between two variables. There are two VERY important things to consider when looking at correlation results, the sample population, and the significance of the relationship. Each correlation study has a sample group of men, 1,000, 2,000, etc. and the hope of the researcher is this sample represents the population. The gold standard of research is pure random sample of sample participants and most samples are not pure, some are better than others. Age, comorbidity, the region where participants live, ethnicity, etc. all affect how well the sample represents the population. Remember the end the statistic solution refers to the larger population, or we make inference about the variable in question to the population. The second critical factor is the significance of the relationship. A perfect correlation is 1, no correlation is 0. See https://onlinecourses.science.psu.edu/stat100/node/35 for more on significance. The real key and most often in research there is a positive correlation meaning based on the statistical test there is a relationship. Now I have often heard and read there is a statistical correlation but not a practical one. One other thought is bias, researcher bias, sample bias and many other biases. I am not suggesting intentional bias. When I did my dissertation, I had a strong hypothesis. The results came in completely opposite of what I believed. At first, I thought I failed. However, disproving or looking for another variable that could explain the result is as valuable as my initial belief about the relationship between variables. I suggest most researchers have bias and the good ones declare it and ensure the research plan accounts for it. In this source are some good thoughts and definitions of many of the terms in research reports. http://researchbasics.education.uconn.edu/correlation/ I was taught to read research reports with a healthy skepticism. Look for flaws, look for the makeup of the sample and how well the sample represents the population. Also look for the significance of the findings. One key to research is where is it published. Peer-reviewed is the gold standard but there are different levels of peers. Being published in the AMA is more rigorous than a local group that formed a website to publish their thoughts. I am not a statistician but do have some experience with research design and interpretation. Please feel free to add your thoughts and experience to this thread. The better we are at understanding the importance of a study, the better decisions we will make. Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: Fingers Crossed

Posts.Content: Justin welcome and I get the indecision. I had been wrestling for months with what to do. For me, it is about really a slow and deep learning curve and deciding what is of most value. I had been heading the RP route and made a different decision and will start HDR BT is 10 days. I am not proposing that for you. Rather take time to really learn about all the treatment options, all the implications for each treatment, and the post-op for each treatment. I believe only with that info fully understood will you be able to have confidence in your decision. I wish you well. Denis

Posts.Content: I went through the 3T MRI and had a lesion. That became a target of the biopsy. DO you know if your lesions were biopsied? The key is "fusion biopsy" where they sue the MRI image and the ultrasound image to guide the biopsy probe to the lesions. You probably know this but I would press for details on the past biopsy or push for a targeted biopsy. P.S. I was under propofal for my biopsy. Keep asking questions!

Posts.Title: PDQ Cancer-Treatment Summary, 2018 (NCI)

Posts.Content: Sharing is a gift in my opinion. I came to this forum and others soon after diagnosis and learned a lot from other guys. I choose to offer my experience to newer guys and find it therapeutic. However, I don't scream it from rooftops. For example, in my men's golf league a guy shared that his PSA had gone up and I pulled him aside and shared my journey. We met with him and his wife and offered our experience and some of our books. To the question of did you influence your friend? No way to know but I doubt it. And if you did that was his choice to make. I have found some very strong personalities on this forum who seem OK with boldly telling me what to do. I appreciate their suggestions even when I think they are not right for me. Information is helpful. However, sometimes one can feel attack by sharing too much, I have had this experience also. Just be his friend, give him an ear to listen, be there for him.

Posts.Title: PSA results are in, not great news, but totally expected

Posts.Content: The decision on which treatment is a process, not an event, in my opinion. It took me 6 months to get to my decision and once there I was relieved and comfortable. I suggest you evaluate the treatment difficulty, the probable (not possible) side effects, the post-treatment recovery process. The main treatments have basically the same effectiveness. What was critical for me was to eliminate my prejudice (in my case about radiation). I heard rectal incontinence and that was a show stopper. With reading, discussing, and advice from experts I was able to be informed to the point of making a decision was easy. Ask questions, take notes, read all you can get your hands on, call guys and talk to them (feel free to PM me if I can tell you about my process. We are all here to support each other! Denis

Posts.Title: First post - stage 4 metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: RJB we are in very similar places and disease stage. It is a most confusing place. I learn best from others experiences not from their opinions necessarily. I also value my docs experience and expertise. I suggest you trust your gut, your intuition after you have met with all the docs. I am also leaning towards surgery and will meet with rad Oncol and try o listing with an open mind. I also have learned that I need to balance my treatment decision with my wife's input. I was heading down this is my decision place, probably base don fear. And I now value my wife's view and opinion. together we will make the decision. Good luck in your learning journey. Denis

Posts.Title: HUMOR - This forum blocked in Turkmenistan

Posts.Content: Hello all, I meet with my new Uro tomorrow. I have generated many lists of questions and have summarized them below what may I be missing? I am hoping for AS if appropriate, so my questions are skewed in that direction.  Am I a candidate for AS  Is my grade T1c, am I low risk? o Cancer volume? <40% 4 cores or 3?? o Psa density, is mine 4.6/35 = 0.13? o Psa history low 4s for a couple of years? o Original pathology report showed 4 positive samples, the first Urologist said may be overlap can you explain that?  What are the results of second pathology opinion?  How do we raise confidence in my current state? o Biomarkers, PHI tests? o Oncotype dx or Polaris 4Kscore test, or CAPRA score (think my score is 2)? o Is there a confirmation biopsy as part of Yales protocol? Biopsy horn anterior  Do finasteride and Tamsulosin confound PSA results and impact state of my cancer?  Epstein criteria is very conservative, what is standard (Yales criteria) now for AS?  Supplements and Metformin?  Assuming AS is viable, what are the components of Yales AS program?  What can I do to contribute to my health (diet and exercise), is there a nutritionist / PT on staff to help review my diet/ and physical conditioning?  What books/literature do you recommend for my education? It has been a long wait and I am hoping this appointment will give me direction. Thanks, Denis
Posts.Signature: 65 YO healthy man PSA had been 4.1/2 for a couple of years, PSA 5/1/17 4.6, Multiparametric MRI, 5/15/17 showed lesion 13 core needle biopsy 3 cores positive 3+3 and one positive in the lesion, may be overlap All cores less than 30% 8/22/17 - second opinion pathology shows a small amount of (3+4) in one core, < 5%, ordered decipher to inform next steps 9/27/17 -Decipher test shows intermediate risk so now exploring treatment options. 2/6/18 - completed HDR BT 5/3/18 Post HDR BT PSA 1.3 9/18/18 PSA 1.2 4/1/19 PSA 1.0 Testosterone 475 Thanks, Denis "One day at a time"
Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: As odd as it sounds, I am hoping for a second biopsy. Confirmation of my disease status is my number one question, as that is the starting point for the decision as to what to do next. I do get this tightrope walk and the pressure of "what if I am wrong" feeling. I think there is enough evidence and with quality AS plenty of time to intervene. I continue to believe/hope that if I can put off radical intervention the science / medical community will continue to improve and a future intervention will have some possibility of a better outcome. We shall see, I am getting to a point that it is less a gamble and more an informed decision. Denis

Posts.Content: Thanks, everyone. I have a binder with all my med info that I will share with docs. I am pretty assertive so time with the doc will be efficient. Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: It has been 13 months since my treatment (HDR-BT) and my Psa has gone from 5.7 to 1.3, to 1.2 and today 1.0! This is good news as the countdown continues. I am told it may take another 2 years before I reach my nadir. I also know bounces are common. I was anxious about this PSA test more than the others for some reason. However, I woke this morning and felt at peace and when I opened my email and saw a message from my doc that new labs were available I was in a very accepting place. Thanks to all for the support and I can now go off to our golf club championship round one with a grateful heart. Here's to hoping for a low golf score today!

Posts.Signature: 65 YO healthy man PSA had been 4.1/2 for a couple of years, PSA 5/1/17 4.6, Multiparametric MRI, 5/15/17 showed lesion 13 core needle biopsy 3 cores positive 3+3 and one positive in the lesion, may be overlap All cores less than 30% 8/22/17 - second opinion pathology shows a small amount of (3+4) in one core, < 5%, ordered decipher to inform next steps 9/27/17 -Decipher test shows intermediate risk so now exploring treatment options. 2/6/18 - completed HDR BT 5/3/18 Post HDR BT PSA 1.3 9/18/18 PSA 1.2 4/1/19 PSA 1.0 Testosterone 475 Thanks, Denis "One day at a time"

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: I have read numerous books, chatted with many online, met with multiple doctors, talked to a few who have gone before me and I am coming to a place of acceptance that I will eventually have treatment. The critical questions that remain are When and How will I know it is time? Active Surveillances intent is to watch those that may have an indolent disease that may not be the ultimate cause of death, ensuring the window of opportunity is not missed, and delaying the side effects of treatment. My Uro considers my case low risk, even with a bit of 3+4, in one core <5%. Now contrasting Klotz and Epstein criteria; I would be a candidate for AS in Klotz model but not Epstein. I believe about 20% of confirmation biopsy upgrade stage and trigger intervention. That also suggests the reminder doesn't get upgraded. The researchers/experts in the field talk probabilities and fortunately paint a good picture about long term survivability for AS candidates. And they point out some die from the disease and /or have a more challenging disease to deal with. My summary of the readings that I have done in the last weeks suggests there is a very low risk of AS contributing to dying from PC, with definitive AS regime and clear trigger points. Whats the debate? For me, it is less about side effects and more about the risk of surgery. I think the potential risk of surgery is equal to or higher than the risk of dying form PC with low-risk disease. Now that is my feeling, not a fact that I can scientifically prove. However, most of our decisions are informed feeling based. I have a friend who chose RP because the thought of cancer growing in him was not palatable. Now his outcome was great so in hindsight great decision. My internal debate can be more accurately described as a narrowing of my view as to the best course for me. I am trying to stay very open to others opinions and experiences, even those who think I might be taking a big risk if I stay on AS. All information is important to inform the next decision. The next decision is the way I am going to manage this. Increased PSA informed the decision to do multi parametric MRI, which informed the fusion biopsy, which is informing the treatment decision. I am awaiting Decipher results to inform the next decision, which I think will be confirmation MRI / biopsy sometime later this year or early next. Some days I feel like I am deciding not to decide but that is not accurate. I am making incremental decisions based on new data and new education. I really feel I am in a gray zone, young enough to have a long life ahead, a cancer that is not in the very low risk category, and I believe a great Urologist/hospital (Yale) that will guide and inform the next decision. I am attending a PC conference next week led my op Docs/researchers in the field, attending a weekend get away with fellow PC guys and their spouses in a few weeks, should meet with Uro soon to discuss next steps. These steps are all to help inform the decision. What I am clear on is there is no urgency to the get it out of me feeling I had the day I was told I had PC. I am throwing a wide net to get information, which I can then narrow through discernment and counsel. I am getting more comfortable with the approach discussed and there are moments of what if you are wrong? that concern me at times. I welcome any thoughts that may inform my journey. Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: ASA thanks, I am not worried or concerned about being on AS. I in the due diligence phase. I post to get feedback, insight and to hear others experience. As I suggested I am waiting for Decipher test results to inform the decision to do AS or something else. My style is to do deep research and gather both quant and qual data to inform the next steps. The more diverse input I get the better my decision will be. I am looking forward to the Prostate Cancer Research Institue conference next week. I look forward to hearing from Klotz and Epstein in particular. Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: new member, first post, got the PC news yesterday

Posts.Content: I might be the person you referred to as deciding against AS using Decipher. I respectfully disagree with your assessment. I had mostly 3+3 and a small sample of 3+4. Guidelines suggested AS is appropriate with caution. We used the decipher data to help us evaluate the caution. Many AS protocols would not have considered me anyway. This data helped weigh the risk. My decipher score was not as favorable as many who have posted results and that helped me decide not to take the risk, due to 3+4. Denis

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: I have read numerous books, chatted with many online, met with multiple doctors, talked to a few who have gone before me and I am coming to a place of acceptance that I will eventually have treatment. The critical questions that remain are When and How will I know it is time? Active Surveillances intent is to watch those that may have an indolent disease that may not be the ultimate cause of death, ensuring the window of opportunity is not missed, and delaying the side effects of treatment. My Uro considers my case low risk, even with a bit of 3+4, in one core <5%. Now contrasting Klotz and Epstein criteria; I would be a candidate for AS in Klotz model but not Epstein. I believe about 20% of confirmation biopsy upgrade stage and trigger intervention. That also suggests the reminder doesn't get upgraded. The researchers/experts in the field talk probabilities and fortunately paint a good picture about long term survivability for AS candidates. And they point out some die from the disease and /or have a more challenging disease to deal with. My summary of the readings that I have done in the last weeks suggests there is a very low risk of AS contributing to dying from PC, with definitive AS regime and clear trigger points. Whats the debate? For me, it is less about side effects and more about the risk of surgery. I think the potential risk of surgery is equal to or higher than the risk of dying form PC with low-risk disease. Now that is my feeling, not a fact that I can scientifically prove. However, most of our decisions are informed feeling based. I have a friend who chose RP because the thought of cancer growing in him was not palatable. Now his outcome was great so in hindsight great decision. My internal debate can be more accurately described as a narrowing of my view as to the best course for me. I am trying to stay very open to others opinions and experiences, even those who think I might be taking a big risk if I stay on AS. All information is important to inform the next decision. The next decision is the way I am going to manage this. Increased PSA informed the decision to do multi parametric MRI, which informed the fusion biopsy, which is informing the treatment decision. I am awaiting Decipher results to inform the next decision, which I think will be confirmation MRI / biopsy sometime later this year or early next. Some days I feel like I am deciding not to decide but that is not accurate. I am making incremental decisions based on new data and new education. I really feel I am in a gray zone, young enough to have a long life ahead, a cancer that is not in the very low risk category, and I believe a great Urologist/hospital (Yale) that will guide and inform the next decision. I am attending a PC conference next week led my op Docs/researchers in the field, attending a weekend get away with fellow PC guys and their spouses in a few weeks, should meet with Uro soon to discuss next steps. These steps are all to help inform the decision. What I am clear on is there is no urgency to the get it out of me feeling I had the day I was told I had PC. I am throwing a wide net to get information, which I can then narrow through discernment and counsel. I am getting more comfortable with the approach discussed and there are moments of what if you are wrong? that concern me at times. I welcome any thoughts that may inform my journey. Thanks, Denis

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: I might be the person you referred to as deciding against AS using Decipher. I respectfully disagree with your assessment. I had mostly 3+3 and a small sample of 3+4. Guidelines suggested AS is appropriate with caution. We used the decipher data to help us evaluate the caution. Many AS protocols would not have considered me anyway. This data helped weigh the risk. My decipher score was not as favorable as many who have posted results and that helped me decide not to take the risk, due to 3+4. Denis

Posts.Title: new member, first post, got the PC news yesterday

Posts.Content: Today is one of those days in the cancer journey that I am keenly aware of how cancer can affect my psyche. I have read about one brother who has passed from this disease, many who are suffering from SEs, and a few that are starting second round treatments because the beast came back. These stories affect me, at times, profoundly. I feel bad for those who are suffering, and I am sure worried that could happen to me. These forums are very helpful. I learned so much form you all and that helped me make an informed decision about my treatment. I also love sharing my journey with new guys, in the hope they may become informed. And there are days where the reality of the journey is heavy. Today it started to feel that way and I had an ah ha. I wrote to a friend remember one day at a time. Now that is a cute saying and a very practical piece of advice, maybe I should follow it! For me, the battle is about the loneliness of having cancer. Sure, we all share, I talk with a few brothers occasionally, attend a support group occasionally, and most of the time I am alone with my thoughts about cancer. One trap I get into is thinking about how my cancer affects my wife! She lost her first husband to stomach cancer. The thought of her having to go through that again tugs at my heart. Few of us know what our disease will do in the future. Today is a day to be lived with gratitude and intention. I am blessed with a life second to none. A loving family, great friends, good health, lots of toys and a keen awareness of the importance of living today. Living today, for me, is about showing up strong, showing up ready to help others, loving those around me to the best of my ability. A good day is when I can reflect on the positive way I impacted those I crossed paths with that day. I have cancer and choose to not let cancer have me! I will continue to learn as much as I can about this disease and the treatments available, I will be there for guys who need my help, I will do the things I know can help me be the healthiest today, and I will live life to the fullest! We are fortunate folks in that we have a choice as to how we will show up today. Lets choose to be Alive and Thrive today!

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: SOrry, you are in the club. I am pretty new here also and one thing I am very clear on is not rushing any decision and the shock of PC definitely will cloud decision making. I read one study that said waiting a year makes no difference to the outcomes. I am not saying wait a year but you have time to make an informed decision. I wish you well. One other thought is the guys on this forum have a lot of experience (good and not so good) and we can learn from them by asking. Denis

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Today is one of those days in the cancer journey that I am keenly aware of how cancer can affect my psyche. I have read about one brother who has passed from this disease, many who are suffering from SEs, and a few that are starting second round treatments because the beast came back. These stories affect me, at times, profoundly. I feel bad for those who are suffering, and I am sure worried that could happen to me. These forums are very helpful. I learned so much form you all and that helped me make an informed decision about my treatment. I also love sharing my journey with new guys, in the hope they may become informed. And there are days where the reality of the journey is heavy. Today it started to feel that way and I had an ah ha. I wrote to a friend remember one day at a time. Now that is a cute saying and a very practical piece of advice, maybe I should follow it! For me, the battle is about the loneliness of having cancer. Sure, we all share, I talk with a few brothers occasionally, attend a support group occasionally, and most of the time I am alone with my thoughts about cancer. One trap I get into is thinking about how my cancer affects my wife! She lost her first husband to stomach cancer. The thought of her having to go through that again tugs at my heart. Few of us know what our disease will do in the future. Today is a day to be lived with gratitude and intention. I am blessed with a life second to none. A loving family, great friends, good health, lots of toys and a keen awareness of the importance of living today. Living today, for me, is about showing up strong, showing up ready to help others, loving those around me to the best of my ability. A good day is when I can reflect on the positive way I impacted those I crossed paths with that day. I have cancer and choose to not let cancer have me! I will continue to learn as much as I can about this disease and the treatments available, I will be there for guys who need my help, I will do the things I know can help me be the healthiest today, and I will live life to the fullest! We are fortunate folks in that we have a choice as to how we will show up today. Lets choose to be Alive and Thrive today!

Posts.Title: RALP tommorow. Oh boy!

Posts.Content: SOrry, you are in the club. I am pretty new here also and one thing I am very clear on is not rushing any decision and the shock of PC definitely will cloud decision making. I read one study that said waiting a year makes no difference to the outcomes. I am not saying wait a year but you have time to make an informed decision. I wish you well. One other thought is the guys on this forum have a lot of experience (good and not so good) and we can learn from them by asking. Denis

Posts.Title: Started Treatment

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis and yes you need treatment. Side effects vary but are better than advanced cancer which will happen in time. You need to learn about the different treatment choices the difficulty of the procedures, recovery time and typical SEs, not the possible SEs. Become a student of treatment. It took me 6 months of study to make my choice. If you want to talk about my journey, feel free to PM and we can talk live.

Posts.Title: Interesting AS video

Posts.Content: For me, it just is logical if my body is healthy it can better handle sickness and disease. Also, I feel better when I am active and at a healthy weight. One of the common themes in PC is we will die with it, not from it. So healthy weight is critical to the main diseases we will face like heart issues, stokes, etc. Denis

Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: I have just about completed reading Man to Man by Korda. I found the beginning of the book similar to how I feel and think. The author describes pre-surgery anxiety and post-surgery pain level beyond what I have heard. He took an air ambulance home and had both a visiting nurse and a nurses aide. I detest pain meds and really avoid them at all cost. For those who had surgery, what was your experience with post op and early at home discomfort, etc. ? Thanks, Denis

Posts.Content: Thanks all, I am still surprised by the number of folks that I have met that little to no knowledge of this option. I got lucky in that the RO I was to see went on leave the department chair took his appointments and happened to be an HDR BT expert. He presented all the options and when I pushed him for the best choice for me he said HDR-BT. I spent some time learning about it and I feel fortunate to have found this doc. Treatmetnb starts 1/26, sencond session 2/6. Denis

Posts.Title: Post RALP good/not so good news

Posts.Content: Second and final round of HDR BT is complete. Had a minor issue and needed a foley. I will go back at 8 am to have it removed. The second round also had more discomfort after catheters were inserted, while with on radiation. Accepted pain meds but that was a mistake. I was goofy until bedtime. One good outcome of foley is I did not have to get up last night! Doc changed my meds from flowmax to Alfuzosin due to insomnia issues with Flowmax. I will see the doc in six weeks to ensure everything is on track and then at three months with first PSA. His plan is to then do PSA every six months until nadir is reached. I am really glad I chose this treatment, Dr. Biagioli, and Florida hospital. The medical staff are all amazing and they make treatment as comfortable as possible. Got to get this foley out so I can play golf today! Must have priorities. Denis

Posts.Title: Post RALP good/not so good news

Posts.Content: Tuesday is my second treatment. So far I have had very few side effects. Perinium was sore for a week but I was able to play golf every day, starting the day after treatment. I had one day of high-frequency urination and the typical 2 days of urinary burning. I am told these symptoms might be a bit more intense after round two. I also had insomnia due to Flomax, and have stopped taking it. My decision to do HDR BT is summarised nicely in this except https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3746400/ Future directions for high dose rate prostate brachytherapy The radiobiological advantage of delivering a HDR per fraction to the prostate while sparing the rectum and bladder, together with the ability to make real-time adjustments to both source positioning and dwell times of the radioactive sources thereby allowing for optimal dose distribution, has led to interest in other indications in which HDR prostate brachytherapy might be applied. One of the main practical attractions of HDR over EBRT is the shorter treatment times, and thus more recent work has focused on HDR monotherapy. This has been predominantly applied for more favourable intermediate- and low-risk disease, in which LDR has been well established. Such treatment requires multiple fractions/implants, typically given over 23 days, with some centres also repeating the implant 12 weeks later. Thus, although the number of hospital visits is lower than with EBRT, they are more intense and require inpatient stay. While the results are not as mature as with HDR boost, monotherapy studies have reported freedom from biochemical relapse rates of 89100% in low- and intermediate-risk patients, which compare favourably with findings with LDR brachytherapy [70-76]. At present this approach is not recommended routinely, but should the long-term outcome data become favourable, this will undoubtedly help to establish HDR monotherapy as a credible option for localised prostate patients.

Posts.Title: AS no longer an option

Posts.Content: ASA thanks for the thoughts and sharing your wisdom along the way. I now enter the second phase of my research and education. I will do a deep dive on other treatments. What is interesting to me is the last week or so I was in a very comfortable place with either AS or intervention. I have learned over the years that sharing, putting out my questions, concerns, and beliefs helps to sort out the fact from the fantasy. My PC education over the last couple of months yields a few things. One, there are no certainties in what we think is the stage of our disease. Two, being well-informed balances out the fear and impulsiveness to act. And three, finding a doc you trust, trusting your intuition, and allowing those trust to inform your plan of action is the course that yields most peace for me. There is little doubt, in my mind, that I wanted to be a good candidate for AS and buy time. I also believe that for a significant portion of men (even those eligible for AS) there will be an intervention. Yesterday the scales tipped towards not taking a risk of allowing a more aggressive disease to go undetected to a point of regret. I also know that intervention is no guarantee and has risks associated with it. In an odd way, this reminds me of my time on submarines. When, as an officer of the deck, I would give the order to "make your depth 68 feet" and we heading to periscope depth, it was time to focus and be all in on that commitment. Taking a submarine, particularly a missile boat, is a complex task to ensure safety and security. Making the decision to intervene, came with great study, awesome counsel and an internal check to ensure it was rational and not fear based. So the journey continues. Once again I appreciate everyone's advice, questions, and shared resources. Life is good and today I will play walk 18holes and play golf. I intend to enjoy chasing the little white ball!. Denis

Posts.Title: PSA Scores are all over the Map. What's next - REPOST from General Cancer Forum

Posts.Content: I concur that you have to ask. The critical info I was interested in how long have you been doing the procedure, how many have you done, and how often do you do them. My doc RO is an HDR BT expert, 10years, more than 2000 and is doing procedures two days a week. SO expertise and currency are important to me. I also highly value the connection I have with the doc. If I cannot easily communicate and trust what my doc is telling me, I need a new doc. Lastly, I think we can at best triage docs into new, gaining experience and experts. Discerning them more than that is a gue in my opinion. so find an expert you feel comfortable with. Denis

Posts.Title: AS no longer an option

Posts.Content: ASA thanks for the thoughts and sharing your wisdom along the way. I now enter the second phase of my research and education. I will do a deep dive on other treatments. What is interesting to me is the last week or so I was in a very comfortable place with either AS or intervention. I have learned over the years that sharing, putting out my questions, concerns, and beliefs helps to sort out the fact from the fantasy. My PC education over the last couple of months yields a few things. One, there are no certainties in what we think is the stage of our disease. Two, being well-informed balances out the fear and impulsiveness to act. And three, finding a doc you trust, trusting your intuition, and allowing those trust to inform your plan of action is the course that yields most peace for me. There is little doubt, in my mind, that I wanted to be a good candidate for AS and buy time. I also believe that for a significant portion of men (even those eligible for AS) there will be an intervention. Yesterday the scales tipped towards not taking a risk of allowing a more aggressive disease to go undetected to a point of regret. I also know that intervention is no guarantee and has risks associated with it. In an odd way, this reminds me of my time on submarines. When, as an officer of the deck, I would give the order to "make your depth 68 feet" and we heading to periscope depth, it was time to focus and be all in on that commitment. Taking a submarine, particularly a missile boat, is a complex task to ensure safety and security. Making the decision to intervene, came with great study, awesome counsel and an internal check to ensure it was rational and not fear based. So the journey continues. Once again I appreciate everyone's advice, questions, and shared resources. Life is good and today I will play walk 18holes and play golf. I intend to enjoy chasing the little white ball!. Denis

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Here are my thoughts and feelings on the PCRI conference. I attended the PCRI conference for the first time. I was struck by the number of men with advanced disease and pleasantly surprised by the number of men on AS and many with G3+4. The keynote folks had one theme and that is seeking docs with high expertise. Caution on using someone who is a part time prostate doc, or said differently more focused on all urologic issues. The point was made there are 2000 published papers on prostate annually and there is no way a doc can keep up with all the literature unless they focus. I was also surprised by the facts that pathologists have a 30% intra and inter-rater reliability error rate, including Epstein. Epstein was asked does he look at all slides that come into JH. He had a tentative answer that if his signature was on it I should have looked at it That did not give me a warm fuzzy. One statement, by one of the lead docs, was made that if your trust your Uro and he trusts the pathologist you should also. One interesting study was done in the UK, protect study, recently reported no sig diff in the 10-year survival rate of a purely random assignment of 1500 men to AS, Surgery, and radiation. They also reported that 40 % of the AS group had intervention within 10 years. That also means 60% of the AS men had no intervention and 60% of the other two groups had an unnecessary intervention. The presenters were critical of their field from a patient focus perspective and a bias towards their specialty for intervention. Many of the men I met had poor experiences with at least one doctor, some a few. Also, the danger of biopsy was discussed at length. Sepsis is a real threat and I met at least four guys who had it and were gravely ill. Many of the docs were discussing the overuse of biopsy. Many of the sessions and vendors were more about advanced stage cancer. Not one presentation or vendor or breakout group on surgery. Genomics was discussed a lot and many felt it and gene therapies are the future. I attended three AS sessions and the theme I gathered from most of the guys was a tug of war between acting too soon and not acting soon enough. However, there were many long term AS guys who said this feeling will pass. Virtually every guy who is new at this had genomic testing like Polaris, Oncotype or decipher. Most of the seasoned guys do 3-month PSA and periodic Doppler ultrasound or t3 MRI. Annual biopsy is on the decline. PSA doubling time seems to be the big warning sign. There was very little reference to Dr. Klotzs work in Canada. Bias seems to be the big threat to managing this disease. Bias by docs and patients. We need to be educated on our disease, be assertive in talking with our docs and at some point, trust our docs or if we cant get another doc. There was much discussion on diet and exercise. Common themes on diet were plant based, many guys went vegetarian, and low carb and eliminate dairy. Everyone seemed to agree that meat is out. I found the conference informative and supportive. I am glad I went. I am not sure anything dramatic happened for me. I am more confident in my current state and current thinking. I do believe many men on AS will have an intervention. There was one guy who shared after 7years he had a successful intervention and that intervention was not available when he was first diagnosed, so the AS delay worked in his favor. It was great to be around a bunch of guys in the same boat (800 attendees) and to have a variety of docs there to explain aspects of this disease. There were about 1/3 of guys with their spouses. It was a good investment and I may go back next year.

Posts.Title: One Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: Right decision? Only you can know that. What was important to me is that I fully explored all the options. I was going to see Patel, I think he is over 11,000 RP now and clearly the guy I would choose if RP was my choice. I was fortunate to See Dr. Biagioli at Florida hospital as part of my due diligence, and as the result choose HDR-BT. I am not suggesting this is right for you. I am suggesting that for me, once I spoke with Dr. B, the right choice for me became clear. I researched and saw numerous docs over a six month period to get the info I needed to be clear about the treatment plan I would choose. If you haven't seen an RO, Dr. B is awesome and has done thousands of HDR BTs. I wish you well in your decision making. Denis

Posts.Title: New Question - Decipher

Posts.Content: I also suggest taking a breath and learn all you can about this disease. I took six months to decide. My biopsy was upgraded a bit to include a bit of G7 (3+4), so treatment was needed in my opinion. I had to learn about each treatment. I suggest learning about how difficult each procedure is, the typical side effects, the post-op recovery difficulty and then make a decision if one needs treatment. keep asking questions. Denis

Posts.Title: 1st Time Poster...

Posts.Content: So I was surprised to learn that the meds I was prescribed for Urine flow may negatively affect glaucoma! What surprised me the most is both docs (Uro and Ophthalmologist) take extensive med and drug history. Apparently, neither looked at it. I discovered the issue by accident. I called my eye doc, and the good news is I have open angle glaucoma and the alpha-blocker is not an issue, more for those with closed angle. As the result, I stopped taking the Alfuzosin, about a week ago and see no change in my urinary pattern. Anyone know how long it takes to stop working? So if you have Glaucoma and are taking BPH meds call your ophthalmologist. Denis

Posts.Title: New Uro and second opinion on pathology

Posts.Content: Thanks for the comments. We are using decipher to validate the current belief that there is no urgency to act. If the Decipher indicates a lower probability of disease progression (my words), we will go down the AS route. Their protocol is quarterly PSA/exam and then we will do a second multi parametric MRI and probably the second biopsy in the next 6 months. My first biopsy had complications so we need the prostate to calm down. I also may partake in a study where they do whole body scans. Not sure the study intent yet. The journey continues! Denis

Posts.Title: insomnia with flowmax, alternative?

Posts.Content: At times I have worried about my cancer. Did the treatment work, will it return, etc. ? What is clear to me is these are all fear-based thoughts. No facts to support them just a negative projection into the future. There is a great spiritual song fear is a liar! that brings me back to reality. I just started rereading Dr. Walsh's 4th edition book and was struck by the frequency he uses the word cure. It got me to thinking about could I be cured? What is clear is my fear of reoccurrence and my hope for a cure are both guesses, neither has any proof today. So, what not live in the hopeful state? It is the holiday season, and many are celebrating a new life, and hope for the gift of life. There couldnt be a better time to choose life, choose hopefulness, and I mean really shift ones perspective to the positive. For me, this shift has a responsibility to act hopefully, talk with hopeful words, be grateful for the gift of treatment that will cure my cancer and so on. We really have the choice, today, to be a shining light to those around us or a vacuum that sucks the life out of everyone. I have really become aware of how much PC can affect those around me. In particular, my wife who lost her first husband to cancer. I have a responsibility to her, to our love to be a beacon of hope, even in times of doubt. I have to watch my tendency to get self-centered when the thoughts or SEs get me down that my behavior does not negatively affect those around me. We have the power to give ourselves and those we care about a great gift this holiday season, the gift of hope! Lets double our efforts to be that beacon, to love with all our beings, to go out of our way to bring peace to those who love us. I wish all of you a hopeful holiday season! Peace Denis

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Here are my thoughts and feelings on the PCRI conference. I attended the PCRI conference for the first time. I was struck by the number of men with advanced disease and pleasantly surprised by the number of men on AS and many with G3+4. The keynote folks had one theme and that is seeking docs with high expertise. Caution on using someone who is a part time prostate doc, or said differently more focused on all urologic issues. The point was made there are 2000 published papers on prostate annually and there is no way a doc can keep up with all the literature unless they focus. I was also surprised by the facts that pathologists have a 30% intra and inter-rater reliability error rate, including Epstein. Epstein was asked does he look at all slides that come into JH. He had a tentative answer that if his signature was on it I should have looked at it That did not give me a warm fuzzy. One statement, by one of the lead docs, was made that if your trust your Uro and he trusts the pathologist you should also. One interesting study was done in the UK, protect study, recently reported no sig diff in the 10-year survival rate of a purely random assignment of 1500 men to AS, Surgery, and radiation. They also reported that 40 % of the AS group had intervention within 10 years. That also means 60% of the AS men had no intervention and 60% of the other two groups had an unnecessary intervention. The presenters were critical of their field from a patient focus perspective and a bias towards their specialty for intervention. Many of the men I met had poor experiences with at least one doctor, some a few. Also, the danger of biopsy was discussed at length. Sepsis is a real threat and I met at least four guys who had it and were gravely ill. Many of the docs were discussing the overuse of biopsy. Many of the sessions and vendors were more about advanced stage cancer. Not one presentation or vendor or breakout group on surgery. Genomics was discussed a lot and many felt it and gene therapies are the future. I attended three AS sessions and the theme I gathered from most of the guys was a tug of war between acting too soon and not acting soon enough. However, there were many long term AS guys who said this feeling will pass. Virtually every guy who is new at this had genomic testing like Polaris, Oncotype or decipher. Most of the seasoned guys do 3-month PSA and periodic Doppler ultrasound or t3 MRI. Annual biopsy is on the decline. PSA doubling time seems to be the big warning sign. There was very little reference to Dr. Klotzs work in Canada. Bias seems to be the big threat to managing this disease. Bias by docs and patients. We need to be educated on our disease, be assertive in talking with our docs and at some point, trust our docs or if we cant get another doc. There was much discussion on diet and exercise. Common themes on diet were plant based, many guys went vegetarian, and low carb and eliminate dairy. Everyone seemed to agree that meat is out. I found the conference informative and supportive. I am glad I went. I am not sure anything dramatic happened for me. I am more confident in my current state and current thinking. I do believe many men on AS will have an intervention. There was one guy who shared after 7years he had a successful intervention and that intervention was not available when he was first diagnosed, so the AS delay worked in his favor. It was great to be around a bunch of guys in the same boat (800 attendees) and to have a variety of docs there to explain aspects of this disease. There were about 1/3 of guys with their spouses. It was a good investment and I may go back next year.

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Yes, there were numerous discussions of the type of intervention does not alter life expectancy. I particularly like this study. http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056...6220#t=article The summary 60% of those on AS had no progression in 10 years and 60% of folks who had intervention did not need the intervention! Denis
Posts.Signature: 65 YO healthy man PSA had been 4.1/2 for a couple of years, PSA 5/1/17 4.6, Multiparametric MRI, 5/15/17 showed lesion 13 core needle biopsy 3 cores positive 3+3 and one positive in the lesion, may be overlap All cores less than 30% 8/22/17 - second opinion pathology shows a small amount of (3+4) in one core, < 5%, ordered decipher to inform next steps 9/27/17 -Decipher test shows intermediate risk so now exploring treatment options. 2/6/18 - completed HDR BT 5/3/18 Post HDR BT PSA 1.3 9/18/18 PSA 1.2 4/1/19 PSA 1.0 Testosterone 475 Thanks, Denis "One day at a time"
Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome to the club one does not want to be in. I was in the same place a few weeks ago and having getting a second pathologist opinion found a small amount of 3+4. My Uro still thought I might be a candidate for AS but ordered Decipher genomic test which came back unfavorable. So treatment is warranted. As to which treatment, that is the really tough decision. I am a fan of removing the prostate and having a good look at the extent of the disease, to inform next steps. I wish you well in your journey. Denis

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Waiting is the hardest part of this disease. Seems like there are a lot of wait 3 months going on in the medical community. I don't get it. If there is no known reason for the PSA to jump like trauma to the prostate, marathon bike riding, etc. why not be retested? I guess if they suspect prostitus then they should treat it?

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: Welcome and keep asking questions. Uros are surgeons and that is their solution. AS is clearly a viable option for you, even by organizations that have strict standards. I would encourage you to learn all you can about this disease and know you have lots of time to make a decision. I would suggest getting a second opinion on your pathology.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results - 2x Gleason 7 +. Need some help.

Posts.Content: Hello all, 65yo Gleason 6 , 3 positive needle core biopsies and one lesion core positive, may be overlap in the samples. I am in the early stage of decision. I am not sure if the 3-4 positive cores excludes me from AS, certainly by Epstien criteria. I am very heathy, no other comorbidites. I meet with new Doc (yale smilow) a week from monday. Any thoughts on AS are welcome. Denis

Posts.Title: Wish me luck... Please!

Posts.Content: Pay attention to your gut feelings. I wrestled with the decision to treat or not. I spent 6 months inquiring, reading, and weighing the evidence. My uro ordered a decipher test to help with decision making. Talked with another PC brother yesterday whose Uro does the same. Once I had all the info decision making seemed easier. I choose HDR-BT. Keep inquiring! Denis

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 Today is my pre-surgical exam combined with my yearly physical. I asked my primary care doctor to request a PSA even though it wasn't in his original order, and in 4 months my PSA rose once again, this time to 9.77. Even though I'm not happy about having surgery in a few weeks if I was on AS this would stress me out to no end. I'm sufficiently stressed with the upcoming surgery! Is there any information that correlates PSA with the Gleason grade found? Stress is difficult. I wish you some peace these next days. I am hearing a lot of guys saying their PSA is not necessarily a linear change, more a bouncing number. This weekend I have met many guys on AS for many years and I am choosing to look at it as delayed treatment. Maybe they will perfect things like laser ablation or invent something new. Again I wish you well. Denis

Posts.Title: My Decipher test results

Posts.Content: Right decision? Only you can know that. What was important to me is that I fully explored all the options. I was going to see Patel, I think he is over 11,000 RP now and clearly the guy I would choose if RP was my choice. I was fortunate to See Dr. Biagioli at Florida hospital as part of my due diligence, and as the result choose HDR-BT. I am not suggesting this is right for you. I am suggesting that for me, once I spoke with Dr. B, the right choice for me became clear. I researched and saw numerous docs over a six month period to get the info I needed to be clear about the treatment plan I would choose. If you haven't seen an RO, Dr. B is awesome and has done thousands of HDR BTs. I wish you well in your decision making. Denis

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: I have cancer in my body and my job is to keep it out of my spirit! The shock of cancer can only be understood by those who have it. I have known many who had cancer and felt empathy for them but did not get the gut-wrenching shock until my doctor said, “you have cancer!” My mind went to almost shut down as he talked, and I am sure I heard little of what he had to say. The first impact of cancer was a profound loneliness and a guttery level of fear that I have never experienced. The early days of being diagnosed were a mess of ignorance and fear, two forces which can do a number on your mind and spirit. I could distract the fear though information, reading and talking with others. However, there were those times like sleepless nights or just a flash of the possible treatments that could send me into a tailspin. Sure, there was comfort in reading other guys success stories and with that come the unsuccessful stories which seemed to overwhelm the success stories. Cancer is a lonely disease. Support groups, forums and the like take the edge off and there are just times that the Dis-Ease sets in in your heart and drags you down. The other force which makes it so difficult is the slowness of treatment decisions and how the medical system moves. I find it discomforting to hear “take you times, no rush, etc.” While this is good advice to learn and understand your options, the fact that months must go by to get to a treatment decision is not comforting. Having cancer is a physical ailment and if I am not careful it will become a spiritual and mental ailment also. This is when fear overwhelms logic and trust. I have had hours of deep confusion and near despair because I let cancer get in my mind and in my spirit. And those around me also suffer due to my discomfort. It is critical for me and those around me that I show up strong and ready to be the best I can be today with cancer. I cannot change that fact, but I can choose how I show up today. I cannot predict how my disease will manifest, how effective the treatment will be and what side effects will happen in the future. But I can decide to be as healthy as I can be today. I can help those around me, be grateful for the life I have today. Yes, I can choose to be grateful with cancer! I have already met dozens of guys who share the disease and we have laughed and worried together, have share advice and experiences, and shared hope and courage. As Movember approaches and our disease will get some awareness, I am committed to keeping my spirit grateful, to be clear about being the best I can be today, and to move forward on the cancer journey.
