Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: Had an awesome first visit with Yale Urologist, Dr. Leapman, an Associate Professor. He spent nearly an hour and a half with us and listened and answered our questions with expertise and compassion. The Dean of pathology revised my biopsy and identified a very small amount of 3+4, less than 5%. We are in agreement to AS and he has ordered a decipher test. He does not think this will change our near-term plan but wants to confirm their belief that AS is appropriate. We discussed interventions and if needed I am starting to think surgery is the best options. While there was some negative news it is by far the best doctor visit I have ever had. So the journey continues. Feeling good! Denis

Posts.Title: New Uro and second opinion on pathology

Posts.Content: Today I was reading a few new guys posts and the wonderful feedback they were receiving. I reflected on my journey to date and was struck by the difficulty I had and time it took to get to a decision. What factors affected my decision? First my decision path was not linear, not rational at times, and certainly influenced by fear. I also was influenced by doctors, fellow PC patients, books I read, articles I read, conferences, retreats, and significantly by the journeys of those that went before me. What is most intriguing to me is how I waffled and even decided early on that I just wanted it out! This wanting it out closed my mind to other treatment possibilities. Being told I had cancer in me was a shock and naturally wanted it out! My first two docs were Urologists and surgeons and they recommended what they do. My urologist at Yale was amazing and recommended surgery. I wrestled with that because he was such a nice guy. Fortunately, I met an oncologist that was equally nice and offered alternatives that I became open to exploring. The forums I participate are dominated by surgery guys, or at least it feels that way. All very helpful, openly share their experience. So, another influence towards RP. The non-RP treatments for intermediate risk guys is infrequently discussed. I find myself comfortable with my decision to do HDR Brachytherapy. My decision centers around ease of the procedure, the simplicity of post-recovery and low impact side effects for most. I will say there have been a couple of times I wondered if this seems so good, why arent there many others choosing it as a monotherapy? I have learned there is less money to be made for the docs and hospitals with HDRBT, so that influences the frequency of use. One of the confounding facts I came across was that HDRBT has declined in use due to the da Vinci RP and the increase in active surveillance. I get the AS but not the RP influence. Sure, da Vinci is better than open, but it is still major surgery with 6+weeks of recovery. Again, I am not arguing with anyone but myself. Clearly, for me, the road to the decision was long (6 months), complicated (saw 5 different docs), and complicated (much to learn). My one wish for new guys is to stay open-minded, take the time deeply learn about options and determine whats most important to you, and then make a most informed decision. Patience is something I did not seem to have but learned to accept the journey will be what it is and I should not try to push the rope! Thanks, and happy holidays everyone! Denis

Posts.Content: sorry to hear about your diagnosis. I think one thing that is important is trust in your doc. I have learned a great deal the last couple of months form reading and sites like these and I am not a doctor (not a medical one anyway). I changed Uros because my first one wanted to schedule surgery right away. My new doc is a good listener, responsive and I feel he has my best interests in mind. So do your research and pay attention to how you feel about your doc. Be well! Denis

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI on Friday

Posts.Content: I also suggest taking a breath and learn all you can about this disease. I took six months to decide. My biopsy was upgraded a bit to include a bit of G7 (3+4), so treatment was needed in my opinion. I had to learn about each treatment. I suggest learning about how difficult each procedure is, the typical side effects, the post-op recovery difficulty and then make a decision if one needs treatment. keep asking questions. Denis

Posts.Title: interesting read cancer deaths falling

Posts.Content: I have not made my final decision for treatment but leaning towards surgery. Incontinence is the one SE that concerns me so I am trying to be best prepared for it. I am nearly caffeine free, which is a big deal for a retired Navy guy! I don't drink alcohol. I just read in Michael Korda's Book Man to man, that avoiding carbonated beverages is recommend? Have others heard that and what additional recommendations do you have to be in the best place for continued recovery? Denis

Posts.Title: Preparing for continence recovery

Posts.Content: A month ago, I sat in a urologist’s office, whom I had only one brief meeting with prior, and he said, “we have mixed news… you have cancer.” Not sure I heard too much after that. Unfortunately, my wife was out of town, as we expected it to be nothing. I did hear the Urologist quickly review the options and clearly thought surgery was my best bet and he could do it before we left for Florida in October. I then went to schedule follow up meeting with him and could not get an appointment for 5 weeks. I left the office bewildered, alone and full of questions. He spent 15 minutes with me. Shock was the feeling I experienced the next few days. I had to call my wife and tell her and her first husband died of cancer. That was the hardest call I have ever made. What made it hard was I was lost, adrift in the sea of cancer. So, I embarked on learning about the disease and options. A good friend had just been through a scary bout with cancer and she recommends Yale-Smilow, which I considered and choose them. My data was in the low-risk category, I was to learn. Low PSA, low volume of cancer in the biopsy. I had a fusion biopsy after a multiparametric MRI, which showed a lesion. The biopsy focused on that and took 12 other samples. All came back Gleason 6, 3 or 4 positive cores out of 13, two <30% and 2 < 5%. Yale redid the pathology and believe one had a very small amount of G7 <5%. My Yale urologist spent nearly 1.5 hours with us and balanced the science with empathy. My wife and I came away feeling we were in good hands. He advocated for AS and wanted Decipher test to inform the decision. I am now waiting for that and continuing my study. I can say that the emotional roller-coaster is still twisting and turning. One day I feel good about AS, the next I think I should have an intervention. Based on what I have learned to date, I do believe AS is appropriate, even though John Hopkins protocol would probably not take me but other leading institutions world. I also believe there is a 50-50 chance I will have an intervention at some point. And there in lies the risk/reward bet! Metastasis is the real enemy, in my opinion. Side effects re the price of admission to prevent metastasis. The docs are very unsure when intervention is needed. Many have thoughts and philosophies about when and they always say, “it is up to you!” What I know: I have cancer, it is low risk, it is growing slowly. I am healthy and relatively young. My family history has no long-life males, I am the oldest surviving male at 65. I know interventions do not mean cure, it can come back. I know the medical community is working hard at new research and there will be better and better treatments as time goes by. What I feel: I have real confidence in my Yale Urologist, I feel he is balanced and clearly has my best interests in mind. I feel he will be clear about treatment when needed. I feel there is a low risk of metastasis getting away from us. And I worry about this! I am most worried about incontinence. So, lost in the sea of cancer is not totally accurate anymore. I now am in a lifeboat with a crude navigation chart. In Navy terminology, I am on a shakedown cruise trying to get comfortable with all the realities of PC and treatment options. I know I cannot sail alone and that my docs and support groups make up my crew. I know there will be rough water ahead and I know I will be ready! I hope I can see the beauty in the world while I am on this cruise. I have a wonderful life and I have cancer. It is not I have a wonderful life BUT I have cancer. Life is meant to be lived! Thanks for helping me along this journey! Denis

AgeInfo.Phrase: also believe there is a 50 50 chance I will have

Posts.Title: My cancer, my journey, my learnings at one month!

Posts.Content: Welcome and keep asking questions. Uros are surgeons and that is their solution. AS is clearly a viable option for you, even by organizations that have strict standards. I would encourage you to learn all you can about this disease and know you have lots of time to make a decision. I would suggest getting a second opinion on your pathology.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: I am facing the same choice. I don't have the travel restriction. My Uro at Yale has done a hundred and that is not enough even though he is wonderful in all other aspects. What seems critical is this is a skill issue. I suspect most Uros are smart and well trained but operating the Davinci and performing a multi-hour surgery in a very tight space is critical. So I am in the mode of finding someone who is dedicated to PC and performs surgery very often. I wish you well. Denis

Posts.Title: What's on tap?

Posts.Content: Pay attention to your gut feelings. I wrestled with the decision to treat or not. I spent 6 months inquiring, reading, and weighing the evidence. My uro ordered a decipher test to help with decision making. Talked with another PC brother yesterday whose Uro does the same. Once I had all the info decision making seemed easier. I choose HDR-BT. Keep inquiring! Denis

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome to the club one does not want to be in. I was in the same place a few weeks ago and having getting a second pathologist opinion found a small amount of 3+4. My Uro still thought I might be a candidate for AS but ordered Decipher genomic test which came back unfavorable. So treatment is warranted. As to which treatment, that is the really tough decision. I am a fan of removing the prostate and having a good look at the extent of the disease, to inform next steps. I wish you well in your journey. Denis

Posts.Title: Polaris Testing

Posts.Content: Interesting. for me I really thought AS would be a viable plan until the second opinion of biopsy showed a small amount of 3+4. For me, it was a risk-reward choice. I also believe (and I may be wrong) that cancer progresses, however slow. My thought about AS was a delaying tactic, not a lifelong decision. I hoped I could delay intervention so the scientific community could advance practice. But the 3+4 changed that approach. I still think AS is a viable option for certain men and that it is critical to have a very ACTIVE approach. Denis

Posts.Title: Is 68GaPSMA PET/CT Replacing Bone Scan?

Posts.Content: Waiting is the hardest part of this disease. Seems like there are a lot of wait 3 months going on in the medical community. I don't get it. If there is no known reason for the PSA to jump like trauma to the prostate, marathon bike riding, etc. why not be retested? I guess if they suspect prostitus then they should treat it?

Posts.Title: New to forum and to diagnosis of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello all, 65yo Gleason 6 , 3 positive needle core biopsies and one lesion core positive, may be overlap in the samples. I am in the early stage of decision. I am not sure if the 3-4 positive cores excludes me from AS, certainly by Epstien criteria. I am very heathy, no other comorbidites. I meet with new Doc (yale smilow) a week from monday. Any thoughts on AS are welcome. Denis
Posts.Title: New to forum and to diagnosis of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome to the club one does not want to be in. I was in the same place a few weeks ago and having getting a second pathologist opinion found a small amount of 3+4. My Uro still thought I might be a candidate for AS but ordered Decipher genomic test which came back unfavorable. So treatment is warranted. As to which treatment, that is the really tough decision. I am a fan of removing the prostate and having a good look at the extent of the disease, to inform next steps. I wish you well in your journey. Denis

Posts.Title: Entering an era of radiogenomics in PCa risk stratification (review article)

Posts.Content: I have cancer in my body and my job is to keep it out of my spirit! The shock of cancer can only be understood by those who have it. I have known many who had cancer and felt empathy for them but did not get the gut-wrenching shock until my doctor said, “you have cancer!” My mind went to almost shut down as he talked, and I am sure I heard little of what he had to say. The first impact of cancer was a profound loneliness and a guttery level of fear that I have never experienced. The early days of being diagnosed were a mess of ignorance and fear, two forces which can do a number on your mind and spirit. I could distract the fear though information, reading and talking with others. However, there were those times like sleepless nights or just a flash of the possible treatments that could send me into a tailspin. Sure, there was comfort in reading other guys success stories and with that come the unsuccessful stories which seemed to overwhelm the success stories. Cancer is a lonely disease. Support groups, forums and the like take the edge off and there are just times that the Dis-Ease sets in in your heart and drags you down. The other force which makes it so difficult is the slowness of treatment decisions and how the medical system moves. I find it discomforting to hear “take you times, no rush, etc.” While this is good advice to learn and understand your options, the fact that months must go by to get to a treatment decision is not comforting. Having cancer is a physical ailment and if I am not careful it will become a spiritual and mental ailment also. This is when fear overwhelms logic and trust. I have had hours of deep confusion and near despair because I let cancer get in my mind and in my spirit. And those around me also suffer due to my discomfort. It is critical for me and those around me that I show up strong and ready to be the best I can be today with cancer. I cannot change that fact, but I can choose how I show up today. I cannot predict how my disease will manifest, how effective the treatment will be and what side effects will happen in the future. But I can decide to be as healthy as I can be today. I can help those around me, be grateful for the life I have today. Yes, I can choose to be grateful with cancer! I have already met dozens of guys who share the disease and we have laughed and worried together, have share advice and experiences, and shared hope and courage. As Movember approaches and our disease will get some awareness, I am committed to keeping my spirit grateful, to be clear about being the best I can be today, and to move forward on the cancer journey.

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Thanks, guys, we as men, sometimes do have to Man Up, as they say, and we can do it with feelings. I am 65 years old and talked more about the penis with other guys in the last few months than my entire time before PC. I have caught myself feeling down and sorry for myself and then observed how it affected my loving wife. That is not right, I need to show up better. Today at breakfast we had a good conversation about surgery and how we will rearrange things to accommodate it. Today I try to love my wife and kids by being strong, doing the next right thing and sharing when needed. Together we can do this much better than alone! Thanks for being there for me. Denis

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Well, I thought I would start my HDR brachytherapy 1/2/18 but just found out my RO wants a colonoscopy prior to treatment. So everything gets pushed a few weeks. My journey started in last August. I sought a few opinions, visited a few docs, read a great deal and learned much from you all. It will be six months from diagnosis to treatment. I am an action-oriented guy and maneuvering this disease has tested me for sure. On the brighter side, I am grateful that I went down this winding road because it brought me to a treatment, that I wasn't even aware of the last August. My first uro wanted to schedule surgery the day he told me I had cancer! Here is an interesting coincidence. In my foursome yesterday on the final day of a two-day tournament, 2 guys had RP and one was going to the VA after the round because they think he has PC. So all four of us are int eh club. I explained HDR brachytherapy and the two RP guys wished they were presented that option. I don't suggest anything to anyone else. We each value different things. HDRBT is my choice. P.S. in our foursome we captured the top three spots in the tourney. I cam in second, it was a good day!

Posts.Title: patience

Posts.Content: Yes, the colonoscopy is mainly to ensure there are no complications with eh radiation treatment. As to bias, I find that comment on this forums occasionally. We are all biased. Decision making is defining the outcome priorities that are the goal, decerning best path to gather information to support decision making and discern the options to yield the best path to achieve the outcome. PC has three most common treatments, each of us will choose based on the info we gather. In the end, WE choose, based on our beliefs and values, which is clearly biased. I have been in this process for nearly 6 months and it was a meandering path. A few weeks ago surgery seemed the best choice but with new information and a new doc that we like, the decision shifted and it feels good and solid for our goals. Bias is often used in a negative connotation and I humbly suggest it may be offensive to some. it is gee if I am biased and I making the wrong decision. All decisions about treating PC are biased and I suggest if we have done our due diligence it can be a positive bias. I have met many men over the last months who abdicated to their docs, so no bias, and regretted not taking time to learn more. I do not know what the percentages of treatment choices are but it seems there is a strong bias towards surgery on these forums. Clearly more posts about surgery than other treatments. I am happy for those who choose surgery to have fellows to share their experience. I do not think each of those who choose surgery was biased in a negative way. They arrived at their decision in a way that felt right to them. While I am happy with my path and decision, I still wonder occasionally about the choice. I have little doubt choosing treatment seems to be the hardest part of this disease. And I am certain the choice I made is the right one for me and my family. So I choose HDR BT. Denis

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Thanks, guys, we as men, sometimes do have to Man Up, as they say, and we can do it with feelings. I am 65 years old and talked more about the penis with other guys in the last few months than my entire time before PC. I have caught myself feeling down and sorry for myself and then observed how it affected my loving wife. That is not right, I need to show up better. Today at breakfast we had a good conversation about surgery and how we will rearrange things to accommodate it. Today I try to love my wife and kids by being strong, doing the next right thing and sharing when needed. Together we can do this much better than alone! Thanks for being there for me. Denis

Posts.Title: Targeted Prostate Biopsy using MR-Ultrasound Fusion

Posts.Content: Diesledog, I get the waiting thing sucks! I also spent some wasted time wondering how and why I got PC. I am healthy, I work out, I eat a PC friendly diet for decades, no family history (but no males lived past 65), Don't smoke, etc. But the reality is I have PC. What I am learning, the hard way is to watch my expectations. My genomics test came back less than favorable, which was a let down in a way but helped tip the decision scales to treat, which was the reason we did the test. I do hope your test comes out favorable. Stay busy to keep your mind off PC, easier said than done. Be well. Denis

Posts.Content: I clearly understand they are different. And I am sure there is relatedness in that 12 catheters in the prostate would cause a spike in PSA like a biopsy. So that PSA has to dissipate to get a true reading. Yes, the radiation changes the cancer cells and that takes many months to see the total effect.

Posts.Title: Any good studies on how long it takes for PSA to return to baseline post prostate bx?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had HDRBT a month ago and am absolutely back to normal (don't ask my wife if I am normal!). The procedures (2) were nonevents, I played golf both times the next day. As ASA suggested it is not new, newer as a monotherapy. One of the big questions I had to my doc was if this is so easy and effective, why aren't more folks doing it? He said with a smile there is not much money to be made. Two treatments and done. Statistically, it is as good as other primary treatments. If there is anything I can do to help let me know. It took me about 5 months to make a decision, and once we truly understood the options it was an easy choice for us. I am not suggesting this is the right answer for everyone but do your research and the right choice will appear. Denis

Posts.Title: Bursted bubble or unnecessary worry?

Posts.Content: My journey to date concerning PC has been typical based on what I hear from other men. However, during the journey, nothing feels typical. This was my first serious medical condition at age 65. I have been living a healthy lifestyle for decades and felt good about life. When the doctor told me I have mixed news, you have cancer my spirit shifted, my inner being was bitch slapped! These last seven months have been quite the trip. I saw a post today from a new guy about treatment decision and boy could I connect with his concern, his fear, and his panic to act! My first Uro was willing to schedule surgery during that first visit! I am usually a very decisive man, let's get on with it and take action has served me well my entire life. As a retired Submarine Officer, we were trained and paid to act. What I had to shift in my mind, in my being was that researching, learning, and investigating are actions. I would suggest it is the most important form of action. PC is a complicated disease, treatments are varied, and individual needs and values play a big role in how to proceed. I needed time to sort through all of this. Even though the number of delays I faced seemed, at the time, to be unbearable, the truth is those delays gave me time to settle into my situation. It did not take long for me to get the implications of having cancer. It is simple to understand that most of us will not die from this disease. However, I detest the comment, well if you are going to have cancer, have PC! Sure, there are more devastating diseases, PC is serious enough for me. My journey, to date, is one of shock, fear, confusion, clarity, more confusion, and finally clarity. We need not minimize the shock. Cancer is a bad word! Then there is the double shock, once one learns of the side effects and treatment complications some experience. But for this patient, the biggest dilemma is the unknown state of ones disease. We have our Gleason scores; PSA and we regularly hear about post-treatment upgrades and reoccurrence. This is what cancer is about. Yes, thats the elephant in the room, will it come back? What I know at this stage is that is a question that has no answer and there is nothing I can do to address it, so I am going to stay the course, live life to its fullest and do the next right thing. My first treatment is next Tuesday. I am going the HDR BT route. Two treatments over two weeks. I am so at peace that it surprises me. I have many to thank for this current state. My wife and kids, friends who know my journey, PC friends who have shared their journeys/insights with me, the Docs who took their times to help educate me, and for these forums. I am sitting on a plane, listening to John Denver songs, on my way to ski with my oldest son. I just left Florida, where we live in the winter and where my amazing wife and I live a full life, my wife and are blessed with 7 kids between us and 7 grandkids! Life is awesome! Cancer tried to take that peace and gratitude from me and with your help, it did not win. I do not know what my PC journey will be but I know I have an amazing life and family friends who make life joyful. Lets not forget the goodness, keep cancer out of our spirits! I wish you all peace! Denis

Posts.Title: Observation, Statistics, Coincidences?

Posts.Content: Got an unexpected call from my ROs office for a preop call. The nurse was great and went over everything in detail and it is pretty simple. I was caught off guard, in part, due to I have had PC out of my mind mostly for a couple of weeks. Having made the decision treatment I guess brought relief. And the call snapped me back to the reality that it is still there and needs to be treated. I am in a good place and actually want it to be over with. 7 months waiting is a long time for me. 10 days to first treatment and then two weeks later for the secind round. The procedure is pretty simple. Under general anesthesia, they insert the caterers in the peritoneum. Bring you back to consciousness and then in another lab insert the radiation source for a fixed amount of time. They then knock you out again and remove the caths. about a half day event, I am told. The only minor issue was the dates got screwed up and I have to cut my ski trip short by one day. I will be in Utah with my son for a couple days os skiing prior to the surgery. Glad this next phase of the journey is about to happen. Denis

Posts.Content: An interesting thought crossed my mind yesterday related to this thread. In the early months, PC was on my mind most of my waking hours. Now the only time I really think about it is int he morning when I read these forums. And I find these forums helpful and educational. If I am to have a relapse in my cancer, I will have more information o deal with eh next steps then I did when I was first diagnosed. I have a couple of friends that find ignorance or denial as a better method to deal with PC. To each his own.

Posts.Title: polyphenois

Posts.Content: Last night I had a long chat with a friend, whose dad has bad blood cancer. The topic of fear came up and we spent quite a bit of time discussing how fear can cloud reality. Some years ago, a friend shared with me about another disease I have a useful tool. Ask yourself two questions when you are fearful. What do I know and what do I think? Fear is often triggered by what we think not what we know. For many, it launches us into projecting the future and often it is dark future. However, we can focus on what we know which is more a cognitive process based on reality, which can lead to a more rational assessment of our current condition and the next steps we need to take, which can help us lead a more peaceful life today. Being in today is the goal, in my opinion. My experience with PC for the last almost 18 months were periods of shock, confusion, fear, understanding, decision making, treatment, and many more days of peace since treatment. I continue to find talking with other guys with PC very helpful. The gift of sharing your experience and letting newer guys know these phases are normal is a gift to self and to them! In the field of Alcoholism, there is a common belief that it is a three-fold disease of mind, body, and spirit and that a threefold recovery is needed. I suggest this is not too far off for us with PC. For most of us there are few body symptoms but once diagnosed many of us are challenged trying to understand, trying to make decisions, feeling alone at times, etc. I practice sharing, meditating, and trying to be there for other guys as part of my way of dealing with this disease and find it uplifting. I also continue to study this disease to be armed with facts. I have one friend with G9 who a great inspiration to me, as he goes through his road of treatments. I hope I give him some comfort in our sharing. I doubt that I will ever think getting PC was a good thing but clearly, there have been benefits of friends, of a self-awareness of how I need to show up to my family and friends, and a peacefulness most days because my clear goal is to live life today to the best of my ability. So today lets choose life and continue to support each other!

Posts.Title: Choose life over fear

Posts.Content: Had a great preop meeting with RO. I will be doing two fractions of HDR-BT, 13.5 gy, two weeks apart. The procedure entails basically three steps. Under propofol, they will use a transrectal ultrasound to insert catheters, I think 20, into the prostate. They also will insert a urinary catheter for the procedure. I then will be awake for the insertion of the radiation probes. They will do an MRI to ensure the catheters are correctly placed and then the technician and physicist will inset the radiation source. I then will go back under and the catheters will be removed. Two weeks later the same procedure. Doc says to expect some urinary discomfort for a couple of weeks. The plan then is to monitor PSA drop over the next year or so. He warned me there could be a bounce in PSA. They are not sure why this occurs but also said bounce patients seem to do better. I am grateful for my doc, easy to talk to and I totally trust him. He has done over 1,000 HDRBTs. I am at peace and comfortable with this next phase of my health journey.

Posts.Content: I am six weeks post-treatment using HDR BT performed by Dr. B. I am 100% normal (my wife may disagree). All systems work as good or better than pretreatment. If there is anything I can do ask. I live in Clermont. My first treatment was a non-event. Second I had more discomfort during the procedure and let them give me pain meds and that made it worst as I may be allergic to the pain meds. And the pain meds contributed to needing a cath for 12 hours. Other than that it was an easy procedure. I played golf the next day on both occasions. I did not have space oar and doc said not needed. Denis

Posts.Title: Had preop call with nurse for HDR BT, guess this is real!

Posts.Content: Got an unexpected call from my ROs office for a preop call. The nurse was great and went over everything in detail and it is pretty simple. I was caught off guard, in part, due to I have had PC out of my mind mostly for a couple of weeks. Having made the decision treatment I guess brought relief. And the call snapped me back to the reality that it is still there and needs to be treated. I am in a good place and actually want it to be over with. 7 months waiting is a long time for me. 10 days to first treatment and then two weeks later for the secind round. The procedure is pretty simple. Under general anesthesia, they insert the caterers in the peritoneum. Bring you back to consciousness and then in another lab insert the radiation source for a fixed amount of time. They then knock you out again and remove the caths. about a half day event, I am told. The only minor issue was the dates got screwed up and I have to cut my ski trip short by one day. I will be in Utah with my son for a couple days os skiing prior to the surgery. Glad this next phase of the journey is about to happen. Denis

Posts.Content: great discussion. I have not been a supplement guy. The issue is the double edge sword. Does the supplement actually help or just delay? Depending on age delay may be a good thing. Also does the supplement cause other damage has to be considered. It seems logical that how we fuel our bodies has an impact on health and healing. And research into PC always takes a very long time. For those of us in our sixties and seventies, the timeline for proving research may be too late to help us, so do we gamble a bit and try promising ideas? Thanks, guys for the thoughts. Denis

Posts.Title: Pathology report is in

Posts.Content: On this day of gratitude, I find myself at peace and grateful for my life, my family, my friends, and my cancer! For me, I must accept all my life and be grateful, because if I am selective about what I am thankful for, my reservations hold me back from being truly grateful. Gratitude needs to be all in! Cancer has brought me many new friends, great docs and medical professionals, and allowed me to reconnect with the truly important things in life which include family friends and being of service to those I encounter each day. I have had the honor to share 1/1 my cancer journey with a handful of newly diagnosed guys and am very grateful for that. Many of you have supported me in times of confusion, for which I am extremely grateful. Gratitude is both a gift and a choice in my opinion. How I choose to look at my life in this moment is where I have power. I choose to be grateful for the many gifts and challenges. I choose to show up today grateful and show my gratitude to those I encounter. As I sit here this early Thanksgiving morning, reflecting on my life and the gifts I have, it is easy to be grateful. I wish you and your families a grateful day and thanks for being there for me and other guys! Peace Denis

Posts.Title: Pathology report is in

Posts.Content: Cancer is a physical illness and does not have to be a mental or spiritual illness. I have only been dealing with PC for 1 year and at times I let it darken my spirit and my thinking. I have been selfish and inconsiderate to those around me. I have allowed the disease to take away some of todays because I was worried about tomorrows. There are days when I read others posts and allow the darkness to creep back in. I feel the pain in love ones, the fear of those with the disease and I get it! We all deal with this disease in different ways and I am clear that what works best for most of us is sharing our journey, connecting with others and allowing our fears and pain to be out in the open. I also believe and am trying to practice not allowing this disease to take today from me and my friends and family. Cancer can be lonely and scary! I get trapped some days thinking about what might happen and it is usually a negative thought. Why dont we project positive outcomes, cures? Because of fear! I stumble across a great song lately called Fear is a liar! That title is what I need to lean on. I have no clue what the future brings, never have and never will. However, when I look back at all the life hurdles I have faced, the outcomes were always way more positive than I projected. We have the power to be in today, in this moment and relish the gifts in front of us right now! I get some of us are really sick, and the treatments are hard, and I wish peace for each of you today. Lets be a force of good, of helping those around us live with dignity and gratitude today. We can look for goodness each moment and try to be there for others. Sure, there will be days of anxiety, sickness, pain, and worry. Lets try to shrink those to moments and look for the gifts, not the trials. Today I was experiencing some SEs and feeling sorry for myself. Then we played golf with my one son and later in the evening we had dinner with my 5 kids and 5 grandkids. Got to put the little ones on a merry go round, bought them ice cream and I just loved them. My kids were laughing and kidding each other, none of them was thinking about my cancer. I had the chance to see the awesome life I have with cancer. I am grateful for my life today and cancer is part of that I today I will not let it take my spirit! Together we can be strong and when needed lean on each other. Together we can learn together and help each other navigate this cancer journey. Together we can be a beacon of hope for those that come after us and a light of peace to those at the end stages. So today let us join together to say yes, we have cancer and we will not let it take our spirit, our peace of mind, and our ability to be the best men we can be for those around us! We got this it does not have us!!!!!

Posts.Title: Fear is a liar

Posts.Content: My understanding and much discussion on this topic at the prostate conference are one PSA is the best measure we have and it is not perfect. Many guys have strong fluctuations in PSA levels. One guy shared he had swings as much as 10 points. PSA trend or doubling time may be the best indicator of progression. There was a lot of discussions and a presentation of prostatitius and its impact on PSA, so the other metric that may be important may be PSA density. Large prostates produce more PSA than small ones. So PSA / prostate size is something to watch and discuss with doc. virtually all men have an increasing size of their prostate as they age. Finally, once we know we have PC, we are now in the mode of monitoring signs of progression and indicators that action is needed. Often the action is more tests like doppler scans or MRI, and possibly follow up biopsies. Denis

Posts.Title: Question about PSA levels

Posts.Content: I am a few weeks post-HDR BT. I choose it due to the simplicity of the procedure, the success rate and the minimal SEs. The first procedure was a non-event. I was sedated, catheters inserted (15) in the perineum. Then I was awake for an hour or so and during this time they inserted leads n the catheters and then the radiation. I was then repeated to remove the catheters. I woke feeling good and once I urinated was able to go home. I played golf the next day. I bottom was a bit sore for a week. The second treatment was the same except a bit more discomfort in the perineum. I had no pain meds with the first round. While I was awake int he second round they gave me pain meds and I found them to be worse than the pain. The biggest post-op issue I had was urinary burning for a few days. The second round the doc had me double up on AZO (an OTC med) and there was little to no burning. The other minor SE is I cannot stop urination when standing, I have to wait until the bladder is nearly empty. Doc says this will pass in a couple of weeks. Again I played golf the next day after. I am now as normal as I get. I take Alfuzosin to help urination but I am not sure I need it. If you would like to talk about this, private message me and I will share my phone number. I am absolutely pleased with my treatment choice and I am certain it is a good choice for many others. I wish you well. Denis

Posts.Title: Ldr....vs...hdr...brachytherapy

Posts.Content: So this morning I was wondering about positive news about PC, and specifically about HDR BT, the treatment I chose. One peer-reviewed article offered "RESULTS: The mean follow-up was 5 years (range, 0.2-15.3). For the 611 patients, the 5-year and 10-year biochemical control (BC) rates were 77% and 73%, disease-free survival (DFS) was 67% and 49%, and cause-specific survival (CSS) was 96% and 92%, respectively. BC at 5 years for Group I patients was 96%, for Group II 88%, and for Group III patients 69%. CSS at 5 years was 100% in Group I, 99% in Group II, and 95% in Group III patients. In univariate and multiple regression analyses for BC, risk group, stage, iPSA, and GS were significant in predicting failure. However, age, follow-up interval, and ADT did not." I have read this article before but never focused on " and cause-specific survival (CSS) was 96% and 92%" I have not seen CSS mentioned in any other discussion. Here is a definition: cause-specific survival listen (kawz-speh-SIH-fik ser-VY-vul) The length of time from either the date of diagnosis or the start of treatment for a disease, such as cancer, to the date of death from the disease. Patients who die from causes unrelated to the disease are not counted in this measurement. In a clinical trial, measuring the cause-specific survival is one way to see how well a new treatment works. I also found form the ACS Survival rates for prostate cancer According to the most recent data, when including all stages of prostate cancer: The 5-year relative survival rate is 99% The 10-year relative survival rate is 98% The 15-year relative survival rate is 96% So the news or odds are pretty good for the vast majority of folks. For those of us who caught it early, I suspect the odds are a bit better. My point was to remind myself and others that we have a good chance of many years of disease-free living. I had a terrific day yesterday and am feeling extra encouraged. Ran a sub 30 minute 5K and shot 78 on the golf course. These are numbers that make me feel great! Have a great day all.
